In-depth review of the theories and empirical research in the discipline of organizational behavior. Topics include: personality, motivation, job design, leadership, and others.
Research leading to the doctorate. Open only to Marshall Ph.D. students specializing in Management and Organization. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Decision Making in the Food Industry
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Evaluate the nature, causes, and consequences of deviations from optimal choice. Leverage psychological insights about how the brain works to make better decisions. Duplicates credit in MOR 560.

Frameworks for innovating strategically to strengthen critical thinking skills to develop creative and innovative business solutions. Discover and create growth opportunities in the food industry. Duplicates credit in MOR 564.

COURSE_TITLE: Fundamentals of Library and Information Science
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An overview of the history of recorded knowledge from ancient times to the digital age informed by the cultural implications of those eras. Open only to Library and Information Science majors.
The development of library collections in all formats emphasizing clientele interest, usage patterns, bibliographical and website sources.

Study and guided practice of traditional and contemporary choreographic repertory. Emphasis in choreographic intention, stylistic approaches and performance technique.
Study and guided practice of traditional and contemporary choreographic repertory. Emphasis in choreographic intention, stylistic approaches and performance technique.
An introduction to improvisational and composition skills that start to prepare students for the creative processes of dancing, dancemaking and performance.

An introduction to various genres within Dance and New Media, including simple hands-on work with existing and emerging technologies used in creating and delivering media-dance works. No previous dance experience is required.

African Dance technique at the beginning/intermediate level: knowing, understanding, experiencing culture, emphasizing cultural traditions, community outreach and diversity; works through artistic process, practice, performance, and related activities, using dance, theatre and music work rooted in t he African tradition and contemporary African aesthetics; focus on West and Central African traditional dance and music.

An introduction to methods developed from modern and post-modern dance techniques, including the study of the rebellious, individualistic, and democratic nature of dance in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Continued study in the fusion of modern, post-modern dance and classical ballet techniques encompassing the study of the democratic nature of dance and choreographic composition in the 20th and 21st centuries.
Elementary to intermediate-level pointe technique for women and men, including strengthening exercises, barre and center work, and variations from classical and contemporary ballets.

An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

Continued study of Classical Ballet technique with intermediate-level barre and center work, focusing on developing greater clarity, coordination, musicality, and knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

Advanced study of Classical Ballet technique with emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Introduction of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and pointe work.
Elementary to intermediate-level pointe technique for women and men, including strengthening exercises, barre and center work, and variations from classical and contemporary ballets.
An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.
An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.

Continued study of Jazz Dance technique at the intermediate level, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, center work, performance techniques, and strength/stretching series.
Advanced study of Jazz Dance technique, focusing on Broadway, commercial, and concert Jazz Dance, with a continued emphasis on improvisation, center work, and performance techniques.

An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.

Continued study of Hip Hop Dance elements on an intermediate level, augmenting the historical context, technique, fluidity, and musicality required to execute the form with greater movement acuity.

Introduction to International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of ballroom dance, emphasizing partner connection, communication, and creativity, with the practical application of dance within a social setting.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Information Technology in Orthodontic Practice
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Follows ORTH 708 and is designed to provide background and up-to-date information on advanced technologies in orthodontic practice.
Primary orthodontic techniques and basic diagnostic procedures. Typodont treatment of malocclusion, record taking, retention appliances, and beginning biomechanics.
Clinical orthodontics; clinical techniques, diagnostic procedures, and applied clinical therapy to selected cases of malocclusion with emphasis on therapy and supervised treatment.

Advanced diagnosis and treatment of complex orthodontic cases. Asymmetrical treatment. Hours vary.
Office management and patient relations in orthodontic practice.

Clinical orthodontics; clinical techniques, diagnostic procedures, and applied clinical therapy to selected cases of malocclusion with emphasis on therapy and supervised treatment.

Discussion of literature related to specialty practice of pediatric dentistry.  Biologic considerations in operative dentistry, odontogenesis, dental trauma, physiology of occlusion, pulpal biology.  Graded CR/NC.
Critical analysis of current pediatric dentistry literature and case conferences related to the application of contemporary issues in dentistry for the complex child patient.
Recognition, evaluation, and treatment of developing orthodontic problems appropriate to the pediatric dentist; emphasis on diagnosis; laboratory experience included.
Clinical application of advanced pediatric dentistry techniques in routine and special problem cases in the outpatient environment. Hours vary.  Graded CR/NC.
Clinical application and treatment procedures for tooth guidance, stet and interceptive orthodontics.
Genetic principles of oral, facial, and cranial malformations; technique and theory of clinical genetics, differential diagnosis, and treatment of disorders of the craniofacial complex.
An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in dentistry for children leading to completion of an original research project.  Graded CR/NC.
Critical analysis of current pediatric dentistry literature and case conferences related to the application of contemporary issues in dentistry for the complex child patient.
Recognition, evaluation, and treatment of developing orthodontic problems appropriate to the pediatric dentist; emphasis on diagnosis; laboratory experience included.

Discussion of medical conditions seen by the pediatric dentist in the hospital environment.  Conditions include childhood cancer, HIV, heart disease, diabetes mellitus and blood dyscrasias. Graded CR/NC.

3 Trimester Course Discussions and case conferences related to treatment of patients with oral and facial anomalies: includes interceptive and corrective orthodontics, preventive and restorative treatment, and selected oral surgery-prosthetic rehabilitative procedures. Seminar, 3 hours.

Discussion of issues related to the contemporary practice of pediatric dentistry (seminars and office visitations).  Topics include: purchasing a practice, associateships, hospital affiliations, practice administration and marketing, computers, jurispudence and auxiliary utilization.  Graded CR/NC.
Treatment of the child patient in the hospital envionment. Emphasis placed on treatment and management of children with physical, mental or emotional disabilities.
Clinical application and teatment procedures for tooth guidance, stet and interceptive orthodontics.
Observation and participation in affiliated hospital clinics: anesthesiology, hematology, and genetic clinics; grand pediatric rounds andother conferences.
An examination and analysis of clinical and laboratory problems in dentistry for children leading to completion of an original research project.  Graded CR/NC.

Demonstration of techniques used in intraoral photography for periodontal purposes, emphasis on proper clinical case documentation in seminar presentation and Specialty Board Certification.
Anatomy of the TMJ mandibular movements; occlusal anatomy and their interrelationships; methods of occlusal correction using anatomy and mandibular movements as a guide.
Presentation of clinical findings, diagnoses, and plan of treatment of clinical cases by advanced students.  Graded CR/NC.
Clinical experience in the treatment of patients with all types and degrees of involvement of periodontal disease.  Includes placement of dental implants.  Graded CR/NC.

Presentation and discussion of treatment of clinical cases involving soft tissue and osseous management; rationale for the therapy; surgical wound healing; dental implant surgery.  Graded CR/NC.

Advanced root preparation techniques including design and manufacturing characteristics of various instruments, sharpening techniques, and root morphology as it relates to advanced instrumentation principles.
Clinical experience in the treatment of patients with all types and degrees of involvement of periodontal disease. Includes placement of dental implants.  Graded CR/NC.

Health as an investment in human capital; analysis of the demand for and supply of health services and manpower; health insurance; cost-effectiveness analysis; market structures and the pricing of medical services.

The balance of payments, macroeconomic policy in an open economy, exchange rate determination, exchange rate systems, currency crises, international financial arrangements and monetary history. Prerequisite: ECON 501.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Classical economic theory; its precursors, main contributors, extensions and critics; focus upon the writings and ideas of Smith, Say, Malthus, Ricardo, Mill and Marx.

COURSE_TITLE: Economic and Financial Time Series I
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Simultaneous equation models, dynamic structural econometric models, vector autoregressions, causality, forecasting, univariate and multivariate nonstationary time series, tests for unit roots, cointegration, autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity models, time series models with changes in re gime. Prerequisite: ECON 609.

Examine experimental design approaches for experimental and clinical neuroimaging investigation. Topics on how to develop rigorous experiments to test theories of cognitive and clinical neuroscience.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduces the various approaches used to image the living brain using MR-based techniques. Covers neuroimaging scanning technologies, pulse sequence design, and sources of image artifact. Recommended preparation: familiarity with Matlab. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.

Leading researchers in the areas of basic and clinical brain imaging, computational methods, and informatics formally discuss their work for which students provide written critical review and comment.

Introduces the masters program; includes historical development of training in the health professions; current issues, challenges and opportunities in academic medicine and health worldwide.

COURSE_TITLE: Becoming a Leader in Academic Medicine Worldwide
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Current approaches to leadership within the context of global academic medicine and health professions education; individual applications, group dynamics, teamwork, and interpersonal skill enhancement.

COURSE_TITLE: Competencies in Academic Medicine and Health II
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Learning theory, teaching methods, assessment techniques related to acquisition and reinforcement of competencies related to parient care, practice-based learning and improvement and systems-based practice.

COURSE_TITLE: Professionalism in Academic Medicine and Health
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Acquisition and evaluation of interpersonal and communication skills and professionalism including ethics and cultural competence; within the context of health care disparities and health initiatives.

COURSE_TITLE: Accreditation and Program Evaluation in Academic Medicine
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Evaluating health professions training programs within guidelines of relevant accreditation organizations; models of evaluation, designing plans and tools for evaluation of program elements.

COURSE_TITLE: Designing Research on Innovations in Academic Medicine
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to design and scholarly review of innovations in health professions education; needs assessment, problem selection, use of research methods to study an innovation.

Academic writing for conference papers, grant proposals and journal articles. Recommended preparation: a completed study of an innovation in academic medicine or other health related field that is ready to move to publication.

COURSE_TITLE: Faculty Development for Health Sciences Faculty Educators
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Role of faculty development programs in health professions schools; tools for delivering effective continuing education and faculty development; models for mentoring clinical faculty.

COURSE_TITLE: Fieldwork: Designing Innovations for the Health Professions
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Individual projects designing curricular or other innovations for the home program as an application of Year 1 concepts and as part of the capstone experience. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Maintenance of Competence in the Health Professions
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Maintenance of competence and continuing professional development (CDP) of physicians and other health care professionals; trends, needs, strategies, assessing outcomes, examining effectiveness of CDP programs.

COURSE_TITLE: Capstone Portfolio for the Master of Academic Medicine
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Role of portfolios for teachers and learners; develop a personal capstone portfolio that represents each learners accomplishment of the core competencies of the MACM program.

Lectures and laboratory simulation in anatomy emphasizing structure and function of major organs to include brain, cardiovascular, lungs, liver, kidneys and musculoskeletal systems.  Open to nurse anesthesia students only.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Pharmacology of Anesthesia Practice I
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic principles, uptake and distribution of inhalational anesthetics, and pharmacology of respiratory and cardiovascular drugs. Application of pharmacologic principles to anesthetic management.

Basic theory of anesthesia administration, preanesthetic assessment, physical examination, monitoring. Case management including airway and blood/fluid management, anesthesia machine, and postoperative pain. Lecture/case study format.

COURSE_TITLE: Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency. Prerequisites: ANST 501 and ANST 502. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Principles of Nurse Anesthesia Practice
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Advanced theory of anesthesia management for general and specialized procedures, diagnostic procedures, pediatrics and obstetrics.

Utilization of research, which includes the evaluation of research, problem identification within the practice setting, awareness of practice outcomes and the clinical application of research. Recommended preparation: research course; basic statistics.

COURSE_TITLE: Leadership and Professional Aspects of Nurse Anesthesia
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Emphasis on leadership and the professional components of nurse anesthesia practice, including socialization, regulation, culture, ethics, law, employment, advocacy, and contemporary practice issues.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia II
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to neuroanesthesia, cardiac anesthesia, trauma anesthesia, critical care and pain management. Prerequisite: ANST 509. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

A capstone course that requires student to demonstrate ability to integrate theory, research, and practice through a mentored research experience with direct relevance to graduate specialization. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in the clinical setting with observation and supervised clinical residency. Prerequisites: ANST 503, ANST 504 and ANST 505. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia III
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Correlation of advanced techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory in diverse specialty anesthesia rotations. Prerequisite: ANST 505, ANST 507, ANST 509, ANST 511. Open only to Nurse Anesthesiology majors.

COURSE_TITLE: Advanced Clinical Residency in Nurse Anesthesia I
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Correlation of techniques of anesthesia administration with application of scientific and pharmacologic theory expanded to geriatric, obstetrical, and pediatric anesthesia; anesthetic management to include medically compromised patients. Prerequisite: ANST 505, ANST 506, ANST 507. Open only to Nurse Anesthesia majors.

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Global perspectives; discovery and use of drugs (legal/illegal); poisons. How they helped shape, modify or change history as described in classical literature through present day.

COURSE_TITLE: Neuroimmunology: Focus on Disease and Therapy
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Newly evolving science focusing on the role of neuroimmune communication in the pathophysiology of the central nervous system (CNS) disorders. Neuroinflammation as a target for novel therapeutic approaches.

COURSE_TITLE: History of Western Philosophy: Ancient Period
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Major figures in the history of Western philosophical thought from the presocratics to the Hellenistic period; emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.

COURSE_TITLE: History of Western Philosophy: Modern Period
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: The development of philosophy from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries; emphasis on Continental Rationalism, British Empiricism, and the philosophy of Kant.

a: Electrostatics; thermal, chemical, magnetic effects of steady currents; DC circuits.

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and its Applications
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Relativity, atomic spectra, quantum statistics, nuclear models, nuclear reactions, elementary particles.

COURSE_TITLE: Physical Biology: From Molecules to Cells
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Length, time, and energy scales of life; statistical mechanics of biomolecules and cellular processes; physics of cell shape; biological fluid dynamics; electron transfer and metabolism. Recommended preparation: BISC 220. Prerequisites: PHYS 152 or PHYS 162.

Topics of current research interest in physics and astronomy. Lectures directed to physics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers.  Graded CR/NC.
Newtonian formulation of dynamics; Hamilton's principle; Lagrangian formulation; rigid body motion; Hamiltonian formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi theory; vibrations.

a: Electrostatics, boundary value problems, multiple expansions, microscopic models of matter, magnetostatics. b: Maxwell's equations, potentials and gauge transformations; electromagnetic waves; wave guides; electromagnetic radiation; special relativity.

Vector analysis; infinite, asymptotic Fourier series; complete sets; Dirac delta function; Fourier, Laplace transforms; Legendre functions; spherical harmonics; Sturm-Liouville theory; orthogonal polynomials; gamma-factorial function; complex variables.
Principles of, and relations between, thermodynamics, and statistical mechanics; ensembles, partition function formalism; quantum statistics; fluctuations.

Fundamental concepts and techniques in solid state physics; electron gas at metallic densities; semiclassical transport; crystallography; band structure; phonons; screening; superconductivity; magnetic ordering. Recommended preparation PHYS-518a and 558a
b: Approximation schemes and application to atomic and molecular physics and scattering theory; identical particles; electromagnetic properties of atoms.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

COURSE_TITLE: Practicum in Teaching Physics and Astronomy
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within the physical sciences. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College. Graded CR/NC.

Course content will vary each year.  It will include topics of current interest in research conducted in academica and industry.

Field application of physics in a business or industry setting; part-time employment.  Project to be jointly defined by student, employer and professor.  Open to M.S., Physics for Business Applications degree candidates only.
Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include field theory, many body theory, Green's functions, dispersion theory, and group theory.
Various advanced phases of particle physics. Content will vary yearly; emphasis on superstring theories, advanced topics in quantum gravity, and field theory. Recommended preparation: PHYS-678.

COURSE_TITLE: Selected Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Course content will vary yearly with current interest. Topics covered may include theory of superconductivity, high temperature superconductivity, Green's functions in condensed matter physics, magnetism and transport in disordered metals.

COURSE_TITLE: Research and Evaluation for Social Work with Adults and Olde
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Critical analysis and application of health and mental health research evidence to inform, enhance and strengthen social work practice with adults and aging populations with a focus on evaluating published research, identifying and interpreting available sources of data, appraising practical measure s/ assessments and selecting appropriate evidence-based interventions.
